Sra. Olga, a member of the "Mujeres de Combate," lives in Huizhil. She is 37 years old, and married with 5 children, who are 18, 14, 13, 11, and 9 years old. All of her children are students. Her oldest son entered the State University of Cuenca this year. Her daughter is in the Garaicoa school, and her other three children are in their community school.

Rosa Olga's husband works in construction, and they support each other in good times and in bad. Olga has an ice cream business, and has been working since she was 14 years old. She began to sell for other people until she could have her own ice cream stand.

She tells us that it is going well because she can sell int he snack bar in her community school. She also sells to stores. In addition, she has another business in her home, taking care of some animals.

Her loan will be used to buy a refrigerator because of the demand for her ice cream, and because she needs it to grow her business.

Rosa Olga's dream is to see all her children finish higher education and become professionals.

Sra.María Gregoria is an active member of the communal bank. She lives in the Paraíso neighborhood, in the parish of Baños. She is 54 years old, married, and has five children, who are 38, 35,33,30, and 28 years old. All her chilren are married and live independently with their families. She lives in her own home, which is the result of her effort and work in her youth. Her husband is her best friend, and he helps her with her business.

Gregoria sells clothing. She has her own stand in the commercial center of Cuenca. She has been working for many years in that place. She works from 9 am to 6:30 pm.

She worked with the Espoir Foundation for four years. She left for a short time, but has come back again for the benefits she can receive, and for the ease of payments they provide.

The loan she requested is to increase her business, buying more merchandise for women, men, and children, with a greater variety. Her dream is to not have any debts.

Sra. María de Lourdes Minchalo lives in Huizhil, and joined the members of this communal bank. She is 47 years old, and has never been married. She says that it is better to be alone than in bad company. She lives with her mother, who is 74 years old, and they do not have their own home.

María sells soft and hard grains, like peas, beans, corn, etc. She also sells vegetables and fruits from her region and other cities. She has been doing this since she was 15, in the outskirts of the market in Cuenca, on Wednesdays, Saturday, and Sundays. She works from 6 am to 6 pm, but she tells us that she has not been able to have her own stand.

This is her first loan with the foundation, and she hopes to get more loans as she needs them. The loan is to buy vegetables, fruit, grains, and other products from the region and from other places, so she has a greater assortment to offer her customers. She will also buy some medication for her mother, who suffers some illnesses due to her age.

Her dream is to have her own home, and a car to go to other communities with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase their businesses by buying a refrigerator; assorted clothing for women, men, and children; vegetables, grains, fruits, etc.; offering a more varied stock for their customers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: La Inmaculada (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal La Inmaculada se encuentra en un lugar muy hermoso de la provincia del Cañar, se trata de las ruinas arqueológicas de Inga pirca, es una ciudad de piedra que nuestros Incas construyeron formando allí su fortaleza, también tienen labrado la cara de un inca en la montaña es un lugar muy hermoso que es visitado todo el tiempo por turistas nacionales y extranjeros, nuestras socias se encuentran muy contentas por haber heredado su cultura, tradiciones y por la importancia de llevar en sus vidas cotidianas todo el honor y el orgullo que Inga Pirca representa.

El Banco Comunal  La Inmaculada está formado por un grupo de 10 integrantes hombres y mujeres dispuestas a superarse y surgir poco a poco hacia delante, aquí algunos testimonios.

La  Sra. Esther Yolanda L. P., es socia del Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, vive en Inga Pirca perteneciente a la provincia del Cañar, tiene 22 años de edad, y vive en unión libre con su pareja  hace un año, tiene 3 hijos: de 6, 4, 1,5 de edad, su primer hijo se encuentra en la escuela de la comunidad, no tienen casa propia, viven en la casa de un familiar que les presta por un tiempo, su esposo trabaja como chofer y le apoya en todo, siendo el pilar en su vida, dice.
 
Esther trabaja como empleada domestica en el centro de la ciudad, y  en el poco  tiempo que tiene en  su casa a la crianza de pollos y cuyes,

Este es su primer crédito y le interesa los beneficios que obtiene siendo socia de la Fundación Espoir; con el préstamo que esta realizando va ha iniciar su galpón de pollos, para así dejar de trabajar para otras personas y dedicarse solamente a sus hijos y negocio, su sueño es llegar a tener su casa propia.

La Sra. Mariana de Jesús V. es socia del Banco Comunal La Inmaculada, vive en el barrio Santa Bárbara en la parroquia Santa Ana a unos 40 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 43 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 5 hijos,  de: 22, 19, 14, 6, y 3 meses de edad, sus dos primeros hijos no son reconocidos por su padre y ya  tienen propio hogar, sus otros tres  hijos son reconocidos pero su padre pero no les ayuda en nada;  su hijo de 14 años es quien muchas veces se encarga de la casa hasta que Mariana llegue del trabajo, viven en una casa propia de adobe, es una ventaja acota.

Mariana trabaja como empleada domestica en el centro de la ciudad, también  se dedica a la crianza de  pollos y cuyes,  los alimenta antes de ir y regresar del trabajo

Es su primer crédito y,  se entero de los beneficios y oportunidades de la Fundación ESPOIR gracias a una amiga que le invito a ser parte del banco comunal. Con el dinero del crédito solicitado  va a poner un criadero de pollos para tener un negocio propio y así ir mejorando su calidad de vida y sacar a su familia adelante como lo ha hecho hasta ahora

Su sueño es de llegar a tener una casa de ladrillo para vivir cómodamente sin preocuparse del invierno, darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos.

La Sra. Martha Adriana L. es otra  socia  del banco comunal La Inmaculada, vive en Inga Pirca en un lugar muy hermoso de las tierras Cañarenses, tiene 21 años de edad, vive en unión libre y fruto de su amor procreo 2 hijos de 3 y 1,5 años de edad, tienen una relación consolidada de 5 años y se llevan muy bien, su esposo trabaja en la construcción y viven en casa propia.

Martha trabaja como empleada domestica  de lunes a viernes,  y los fines de semana se dedica a su negocio, tiene un criadero de cerdos, pollos y cuyes, aunque estos últimos se le murieron y ahora está tratando de recuperarse de esa pérdida, también sacrifica un cerdo sea de su criadero o comprado y con ello elabora ornado  o vende la carne cruda por libras, nos dice que la va muy bien en la venta!!.

Este es su primer crédito y se siente muy contenta de haber ingresado al banquito porque sabe que tiene buenos  beneficios  que la fundación ofrece y por las socias que son muy amigas en la comunidad y están dispuestas a superarse

El préstamo que está realizando lo va a invertir en la compra de cerdos para su criadero.

Su meta es llegar a tener una tienda porque son muy escasas en la comunidad y dedicarse solo a sus negocios  y así tener más tiempo para cuidar de sus hijos.
texts.en:
The communal bank "La Inmaculada" is located in a beautiful place in Cañar province in the ruins of Inga Pirca, which is a city made of stone that the Inca built as their fortress. There is also a stone face carved in a mountain by the Inca. It is a beautiful place that is always visited by local and international tourists. Our members are happy to have inherited the culture and traditions of the Inca, and they carry the honor and the pride of Inga Pirca in their daily lives.

The communal bank "La Inmaculada" is formed by a group of 10 men and women, who are all ready to overcome and move forward little by little. We have some of their stories here.

Esther Yolanda L. P. is a member of the bank She lives in Inga Pirca, and is 22 years old. She has lived with a partner for one year. She has three children who are 6, 4, and 1 year old. Her first son is in the community school. They do not have their own home; they live in a house that a family member is lending them for a while. Her husband is a chauffeur, and supports her in everything. She says he is a pillar in her life.

Esther works as a domestic employee in the city center, and in the little time that she has at home, she raises chickens and guinea pigs.

This is her first loan, and she is interested in the benefits she can receive as a member of the Espoir Foundation. With this loan she is going to start a chicken coop, so that she can stop working for other people and dedicate herself to her children and her business. Her dream is to have her own home.

Mariana de Jesús V. lives in the Santa Bárbara neighborhood in the Santa Ana parish, 40 minutes outside of Cuenca. She is 43 years old, and is the single mother of 5 children who are 22, 19, 14, 6, 3 months. The first two are not recognized by their father and have their own home. The younger three are recognized by their father, but he does not help them with anything. Her 14-year-old son often takes care of the house until Mariana comes home from work. They live in their own adobe house, which is an advantage.

Mariana works as a domestic employee in the center of the city. She also raises chickens and guinea pigs, which she feeds before and after work.

This is her first loan. She learned about the benefits and opportunities of the Espoir Foundation thanks to a friend who invited her to be part of the communal bank. With the loan, she will get a chicken hatchery so she can have her own business and improve the quality of life of her family, to help them move forward like she has been doing.

Her dream is to have a brick house, so they can live comfortably without worrying about the winter, and give her children a better life.

Martha Adriana L. is another member of the bank. She lives in Inga Pirca, in a beautiful place in the Cañar area. She is 21 years old, and lives with her partner of five years, and they get along very well. She has two children, who are 3 and 1 and a half. Her husband works in construction, and they have their own home.

Martha is a domestic employee from Monday to Friday. On weekends she works on her business. She raises pigs, chickens, and guinea pigs, although her guinea pigs recently died. Now she is trying to recover from that loss. She also slaughtered a pig from her farm, and she sold the raw meat by the pound. She says that sales are good.

This is her first loan, and she feels happy to have entered this little bank, because she knows the benefits that the foundation offers, and the members are friends in the community and are ready to overcome.

This loan will be invested in pigs for her farm.

Her goal is to have a store, because there are few in her community, and to be able to only run her business so she can have more time to care for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals (pigs, chickens, guinea pigs)

loans.name: Cenaida Mariana

texts.es:
La señora Cenaida es socia del Banco Comunal Nueva Generación, un grupo relativamente nuevo que se reúne cada dos semanas en el Barrio Cuba en la ciudad de Manta, Provincia de Manabí, en la costa ecuatoriana.

Cenaida tiene 34 años, es casada, y tiene 4 hijos de 14, 12, 7 y 5 años. Su esposo es maestro conductor. Ella vende cosméticos Yanbal por catálogo, y también compra y vende ropa de mujer, varón y niño. Lleva 2 años con sus negocios.

Inició solamente con la venta de cosméticos, y dice que es buen negocio porque las ganancias y las incentivas son buenas, y también aprende mucho. 

Ella sale a las comunidades alrededor de Manta como Santa Ana y San Mateo para vender sus productos y hacer entregas a domicilio; ya tiene sus clientes regulares. 

Está pidiendo un crédito para incrementar sus productos Yanbal y abastecer mejor su stock de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños. También le gustaría poner un bazar propio en su casa. 

Lleva 3 ciclos trabajando con su banco comunal; ingresó cuando estaba recién empezando con la venta de Yanbal, y después empezó su segundo negocio. Le gusta trabajar con su grupo, y dice que los préstamos le han ayudado porque ella ahora está aportando más para su familia económicamente, porque su esposo perdió su trabajo por un tiempo. Ahora él encontró un trabajo, pero ella sigue trabajando y aportando para el bienestar de su familia.
texts.en:
Señora Cenaida is a member of the communal bank "Nueva Generación," (New Generation), a relatively new group that meets every two weeks in the Cuba neighborhood in the city of Manta, Manabí Province, on the Ecuadorian coast.

Cenaida is 34 years old, married, and has 4 children who are 14, 12, 7, and 5 years old. Her husband is a driver. She sells Yanbal brand cosmetics by catalog, and also buys and sells clothing for men, women, and children. She has been doing this for 2 years.

She started by just selling cosmetics, and she says it is a good business because the income and the incentives are good, and she also has learned a lot.

She goes out to the communities around Manta like Santa Ana and San Mateo to sell her products and deliver them to homes; she already has regular customers.

She is requesting a loan to increase the amount of Yanbal products she has, and to stock up on clothing for women, men, and children. She would also like to start a variety store in her home.

She has had three loans with this bank. She entered when she had just started selling Yanbal, and later she started her second business. She likes to work with this group, and says that the loans have helped her because she is providing more for her family, since her husband lost his job for a while. Now he found a job, but she is continuing to work and contribute to the well-being of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Yanbal cosmetics and increase her stock of clothing for men, women, and children

loans.name: Carmen Narcisa

texts.es:
La señora Carmen V. es socia del Banco Comunal “La Unión de La Mujer,” un grupo grande de señoras que se reúnen cada 15 días en un centro educativo ubicado en el barrio de Santa Mónica, en la ciudad de Manta, en la costa ecuatoriana. Este es  un banquito bastante antiguo que ya lleva 37 ciclos de crédito con la institución.

La Sra. Carmen es socia fundadora del grupo, entonces ya lleva unos 10 años obteniendo créditos de la fundación. Su hermana mayor también es socia, y el día de la entrevista las dos estaban sentadas juntas con una de las nietas pequeñas de su hermana, Nayeli, la cual les acompañaba este día. Ellas y dos hermanos más viven en el mismo barrio Santa Mónica donde crecieron. 

Carmen tiene 52 años, es casada, y tiene 2 hijos; tenía 3 pero uno se murió. Sus dos hijos ya son mayores y están casados y tienen sus propias familias. Cuatro de sus nietos viven con ella. Ella es una señora muy alegre, chistosa y amable. Trabaja junta con su hermana, María Norma, vendiendo ropa, y también tiene un pequeño negocio en la Playa El Murciélago, donde vende bebidas gaseosas y cerveza a turistas sedientos.

Casi siempre trabaja los fines de semana en la playa, y dependiendo de la cantidad de gente que hay a veces trabaja alli durante toda la semana; lleva 3 años vendiendo en la playa, y aún más tiempo vendiendo ropa con su hermana. Venden más que nada ropa interior principalmente  ropa panameña, y regularmente trabaja en un lugar que se llama Picoazá, en Portoviejo, una ciudad que queda a 40 minutos de Manta.

La venta de ropa sube y baja según la temporada, ella dice, pero por lo general le va bien. Tiene como principio no vender en lugares desconocidos, porque la gente puede desaparecer mucho más fácilmente sin pagar, por eso no le gusta mucho vender a gente desconocida o que apenas conoce. 

La señora Carmen Narciza solicitó el crédito para invertir poco a poco  en sus negocios,  en la compra de cerveza, bebidas gaseosas  y ropa. También piensa terminar el proceso de instalar una ducha en su casa.
texts.en:
Carmen V. is a member of the “La Unión de La Mujer” Communal Bank, a large group of women that meets every 15 days at the educational center located in the Santa Mónica, in Manta city, on the coast. This is a rather well-established little bank as it is in its 37th credit cycle. Carmen is a founding member of the group and has been receiving loans for 10 years. Her older sister is also a member, and the day of the interview the two of them were seated together with one of the small grandchildren of her sister, Nayeli, who accompanied this on this day. They and two brothers live in the same Santa Mónica neighborhood where they grew up. Carmen is 52 years old, married, and has 2 children; she had 3 but one died. Her two children are grown, married, and have their own families. Four of her grandchildren live with her. She is a very happy, friendly, and good-humored woman. She works with her sister, María Norma, selling clothing, and she also has a small business on El Murciélago beach where she sells soda pop and beer to the tourists. Carmen always works on the weekends at the beach, and depending on the quantity of people present sometimes she works during the week. She has been selling at the beach for 3 years, and even longer selling clothing with her sister. They sell primarily underwear and regularly work in a location called Picoazá in Portoviejo, a city located 40 minutes from Manta city. The clothing sales rise and fall according to the season, she says, but in general sales go well. She generally doesn’t sell in unknown places, because the people can more easily disappear without paying, so she doesn’t like to sell to people she doesn’t know or hardly knows. Carmen Narciza is seeking a loan to invest little by little in her businesses, buying beer, soda pop and clothing. She also is planning to finish the installation of a shower in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing, beer, and soda pop for her busineses.

loans.name: Maria Norma

texts.es:
La señora Maria Norma V. es socia del Banco Comunal “La Unión de La Mujer,” un grupo grande de señoras que se reúnen cada 15 días en un centro educativo ubicado en el barrio de Santa Mónica, en la ciudad de Manta, en la costa ecuatoriana. Es un banquito antiguo que ya lleva 37 ciclos de crédito con la institución. 

La Sra. Maria Norma Vélez es socia fundadora del grupo, entonces ya lleva muchos años sacando créditos de la fundación. Dice que le gusta mucho trabajar con el grupo. Ella tiene 62 años, es casada y tiene 5 hijos, los cuales ya son mayores con familias propias. Ya tiene 14 nietos!

Maria Norma vive en el mismo barrio Santa Mónica, donde ella creció, y 3 de sus hermanos siguen viviendo en el barrio junto con ella (pero en sus propias casas). La señora se dedica a la venta de ropa a crédito, trabaja de forma ambulante, va de casa en casa para vender. Lleva más que 20 años con este negocio. Ahora sus ventas están un poco bajas por la situación de la economía global, pero dice que por lo general le va bastante bien con este negocio.

Nos cuenta que a veces tiene que salir a buscar sus clientes para que le paguen, pero no tiene muchas problemas porque la mayoría de su clientela es de confianza. También tiene otro negocio de venta de cervezas y bebidas gaseosas en su casa. 

Actualmente está pidiendo un crédito para poder comprar ropa y cerveza. Dice que su meta para el futuro es seguir con sus negocios y con su banco comunal.
texts.en:
Señora Maria Norma V. is a member of the communal bank, "La Unión de La Musjer," a large group of women that meets every two weeks in an educational center located in the neighborood of Santa Mónica, in the city of Manta, on the Ecuadorian coast. It is an established bank that has had 37 loans with the institution. Señora Maria Norma V. is the founding member of the group, so she has many years of experience taking out loans from the institution. She says that she likes to work with the group. She is 62, is married, and has 5 children, who are adults with their own families. She already has 14 grandchildren! Maria Norma lives in the same neighborhood of Santa Mónica, where she grew up. Three of her siblings also continue living in this neighborhood with her (but in their own houses). She sells clothing on credit. She works by traveling from house to house to make sales. She has had this business for more than 20 years. Her sales are a little low now because of the global economic situation, but she says that in general her business is going rather well for her. She tells us that at times she has to go out collect money from her customers, but she doesn't have many problems because the majority of her clientele is trustworthy. She also has another business of selling beer and beverages in her home. Currently she is asking for a credit to buy clothing and beer. She says that her goal for the future is to continue with her businesses and her communal bank

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise to supply her businesses (clothing and beverages)

loans.name: Zenovia Soledad

texts.es:
La señora Zenovia es socia del Banco Comunal Nueva Generación, un grupo relativamente nuevo que se reúne cada dos semanas en el Barrio Cuba en la ciudad de Manta, Provincia de Manabí, en la costa ecuatoriana.

Ella tiene 59 años y vive en unión libre con su esposo, tiene 8 hijos, los cuales ya están casados y tienen familias propias. Tiene también 18 nietos (más uno que viene en camino) y un bisnieto. 

Zenobia  y su esposo tienen una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su casa, un negocio que operan hace 10 años; además ella tiene un negocio aparte de venta de productos Yambal que los exhibe en  una vitrina en su casa, y vende a amigas, conocidas, y vecinas del barrio Cuba, donde vive ella. 

Ya lleva 3 años vendiendo productos cosméticos, y dice que le va bien porque hay un buen porcentaje de ganancias en este negocio. Dice que ya tiene sus clientas regulares, y que no es buena idea vender a cualquiera, porque hay que saber quienes pagarán sus cuotas y quienes no. 

La señora está pidiendo un crédito para invertir en la compra de mercadería surtida para su tienda y también algunos productos cosméticos, porque sus ventas son a crédito y sus clientas le pagan en cuotas después de que ella entregue los productos. 

Su sueño para el futuro es viajar. Ya conoce Venezuela donde vive una de sus hijas. Le gustó, pero dice que no es tan lindo como el Ecuador.
texts.en:
Zenovia is a member of the “Nueva Generación” communal bank, a relatively new group the meets every two weeks in the Cuba neighborhood in the city of Manta, in the province of Manabí, on the Ecuadoran coast. She is 59 years old and lives with her common-law husband. She has 8 children who are all married and have their own families. She also has 18 grandchildren (plus one more that’s on the way) and a great-grandson. Zenobia and her husband have a small grocery store in their house, a business that they have had for 10 years. She also has a separate business selling Yambal products [a cosmetics company that operates in South America], which she exhibits in a vitrine in her house. She sells to friends, acquaintances, and neighbors in the Cuba neighborhood, where she lives. She has been selling cosmetic products for 3 years and says that things are going well because she earns a good percentage of the profits in this business. She says that she has regular clients, and that it isn’t a good idea to sell to just anyone, because she has to know who can pay their installments and who can’t. She is requesting a loan to invest in buying merchandise to stock her grocery store, and also for some cosmetic products. Her sales are done on credit and her clients pay her in installments after she gives them the products. Her dream for the future is to travel. She has been to Venezuela, where one of her daughters lives. She liked it there, but she says it’s not as pretty as Ecuador.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise to stock her grocery story and also Yambal cosmetics

loans.name: Belgica Maritza

texts.es:
La señora Bélgica es socia del Banco Comunal Nueva Generación, un grupo relativamente nuevo que se reúne cada dos semanas en el Barrio Cuba en la ciudad de Manta, Provincia de Manabí, en la costa ecuatoriana.

Bélgica tiene 26 años y vive en unión libre con su pareja y su hijo de 2.5 años. Ella se dedica a la venta de sábanas, cortinas, y medicina natural. Su mamá le trae las cortinas y sábanas desde la ciudad de Guayaquil, y la medicina natural es de un catálogo. 

Vende de casa en casa, y también viaja fuera de la ciudad de Manta para vender sus productos. Sus clientas son generalmente sus amigas y antiguas compañeras de trabajo. Se dedica a esta actividad desde los 22 años y,  dice que aunque las ventas siempre suben y bajan le va bastante bien, y vende $30-$40 de mercadería cada semana. Le gusta su trabajo. 

Actualmente está pidiendo un crédito para comprar sábanas y cortinas con nuevos diseños y colores de moda e incrementar su stock de medicina natural.  No invertirá todo el crédito en la compra, sino que lo invertirá poco a poco de acuerdo a sus necesidades.

 Su meta para el futuro es poner una tienda en su casa, con vitrinas y todo. Lleva 2 ciclos trabajando con su banco comunal, y dice que es “una gran oportunidad que le brindan” porque los intereses son bajos y los pagos quincenales le convienen.
texts.en:
Bélgica is a member of the “Nueva Generación” communal bank, a relatively new group that meets every two weeks in the Cuba neighborhood in the city of Manta, in the province of Manabí, on the coast of Ecuador. Bélgica is 26 years old and lives with her common-law husband and her 2.5 year-old son. She sells sheets, curtains, and natural medicine. Her mother brings her the curtains and sheets from the city of Guayaquil, and the natural medicine is from a catalog. She sells door-to-door and she also travels outside the city of Manta to sell her products. Her customers are usually her friends and her acquaintances from her old job. She has been working in this business since she was 22 years old. She says that though sales always rise and fall, things are going very well and she sells $30 to $40 of merchandise per week. She likes her work. She is requesting a loan in order to buy sheets and curtains with new designs and fashionable colors and to increase her stock of natural medicines. She won’t invest all of her loan at once in purchases; rather she will spend it bit by bit as needed. Her goal for the future is to open a store in her house, with vitrines and all. She has been with the communal bank for two loan cycles, and she says it’s “a great opportunity being provided” because the interest is low and the twice-monthly payments work well for her.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheets and curtains in fashionable colors and designs and to increase her stock of natural medicine products

loans.name: Decsi Asuncion

texts.es:
Decsi P. es una de las socias del Banco Comunal 3 de Mayo, se reúnen cada quince días en la localidad de Picoaza una parroquia perteneciente a la ciudad de Portoviejo en la Provincia de Manabí.

Ella vive en el sitio el milagro a tan solo 5 minutos del centro de la parroquia, tiene 41 años de edad,  comparte su vida con Cruz Tóala su esposo y  6 hijos de entre 23 y 11 años, Decsi y su esposo luchan a diario por dar a sus hijos mejores días, nos dice todos sus muchachos estudian excepto la mayor que ya tiene compromiso.

Decsi esta solicitando a la fundación un crédito comprar herramientas para poner un taller de ebanistería en su casa, además tienen un negocio familiar de legumbres y frutas  donde todos ayudan, ponen de su parte para  tratar de incrementar el mismo, ya tienen 4 años en esta actividad. 

El sueño de Decsi es que sus hijos sigan adelante, que estudien sean unos profesionales  y porsupuesto incrementar sus negocios y ser independites para sentirse realizados.
texts.en:
Decsi P. is a member of the “3 de Mayo” communal bank, which meets every two weeks in Picoaza, a parish that belongs to the city of Portoviejo, in the province of Manabí. She lives in the El Milagro neighborhood, just 5 minutes from the center of the parish. She is 41 years old and lives with Cruz Tóala, her husband, and 6 children between the ages of 23 and 11. Decsi and her husband work hard every day to provide their children a better life. She says that all of them are studying, except the oldest, who already has a job. Decsi is requesting a loan to buy tools so she can open a woodworking shop in her house. She also has a family business selling vegetables and fruits, in which all members of the family help and do their part to try to make the business grow. She has been working in this business for 4 years. Decsi’s dream is that her children will get ahead in life, that they will study and become professionals; and, of course, that her businesses will grow so that her children can be independent and feel fulfilled.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools for their woodworking shop and to expand her fruit and vegetable business

loans.name: Sara Petrona

texts.es: La señora Sara Petrona C. ella tiene 34 años de edad, es casada y tiene tres hijos menores de edad, son estudiantes. La señora C. tiene una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación. Ella dio inicio a este negocio hace 3 años, ella empezó vendiendo leña, comida y frijoles a sus vecinos. Sin embargo con el tiempo logro establecer la pulpería. Sus compras generalmente las realiza desde su casa, ya que allí le llegan a vender la mayoría de artículos que ofrece. Solamente las verduras y frutas son las únicas cosas que ella va a comprar al mercado. Su crédito será invertido en la compra de mayor cantidad de mercancías, en artículos varios para la misma. Su sueño es llegar a tener una pulpería grande, en la cual venda todo tipo de artículos, que puedan brindar mayores ingresos a su familia
texts.en:
Mrs. Sara Petrona C. is 34 years old, married with three young children still in school. Mrs. C. has a small convenience store situated in her home. She started up this business 3 years ago by selling firewood, food and beans to her neighbors. However, with time, she succeeded in establishing the convenience store. Generally her purchases are made from her house, as that is where the majority of venders come to sell her the type of items she offers. Fruit and vegetables are the only things she has to go and get at the market. Her loan will be used to buy a bigger quantity and variety of merchandise. Her dream is to own a large convenience store, the kind which sells all kinds of goods and that could offer greater revenue for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Agustin

texts.en:
Agustin S. is from the village of Luksoon, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. He is 34 years old. Agustin is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Agustin owns and operates a motorcycle-transport business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport services to local community members. Agustin has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Agustin joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agustin is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Agustin from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en:
Celerina L. is from the village of Panalsalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Celerina is married and has four adult children. Celerina owns and operates a sari-sari or general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both beverage and daily-use products in the local community. Celerina has been engaged in her business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Celerina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celerina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. Celerina is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Celerina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces Lanao del Norte, Zamboanga del sur and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Crisanto

texts.en:
Crisanto M. is from the village of Montol, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. He is 40 years old. Crisanto is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Crisanto owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Crisanto has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Crisanto joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Crisanto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Crisanto is requesting a new loan which will be used to purchase fertilizers. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Crisanto from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher folks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Charlyn

texts.en:
Charlyn O. is from the village of Cabatuan, Calabayan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 24 years old. Charlyn is married and has two school-aged children. Charlyn has a business venture raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting cassava for sale. Charlyn has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2008, Charlyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Charlyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Charlyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma T. is a 39-year-old business owner. She is married to Armando, age 41, and has one son and one daughter. She lives in the busy town of Jala-jala in the Rizal Province of the Philippines.  She is the living picture of a mother whose dream it is to give her children a decent life.

Alma joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2001 with dreams of acquiring capital for her planned reseller business. She has been in the reseller business for nine years now.  It brings her enough earnings and continues to grow and she wants to further invest in her business.

Alma proposes an amount of 45,000 pesos for her 9th loan to use as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for 15 sacks of commercial rice, sacks of rice grains, and sacks of charcoal all for resale.  She dreams of expanding her business. She also aspires of having a personal restaurant and a car for service. Also to send her children to school until they finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To buy for rice and charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Salve

texts.en:
Salve D. S. hails from the busy town of Tanay, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 33 years old and the mother of a daughter, Fatima. She is married to Arnel, who is 34 and her business partner. She is busy managing her business.

She wanted to help her husband make a living. She really wanted to start a business that she could manage within her capacity as a woman. Her problem was the capital to start a business. Then she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008. When she received her first loan, she started a business reselling rice, charcoal and other products. After almost a year of doing the business, she finds it profitable.

Now she is requesting a loan of 10,000 pesos as her second loan and this will be used to pay for charcoal, nine sacks of rice and transportation expenses. She is hopeful that her business will grow and will bring enough profit for her to save for the future of her child. She also wants to improve her sewing business as her secondary source of income.

loans.use: To pay for charcoal worth 5,000 pesos, nine sacks of rice and transportation expenses

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita S. is a native of Tanay, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is 57 years old and the wife of Ildifonso, who is a 62-year-old welder. She is a mother to two sons and two daughters, all of legal age already.

When some of her children settled down, she believed that she needed to have her own source of income and have a business that she could manage considering her age. In 2008, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with bagful of hope of having access to capital to sustain her business.

Her previous loans were carefully invested as rolling capital for her general store. She is very careful with the inventory and with monitoring the inflow and outflow of her capital. The business brings her enough income for a living.

Now on her third loan, she is proposing an amount of 13,000 pesos as additional capital for her general store. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for four sacks of rice, 10 sacks of charcoal, groceries, soft drinks and other basic commodities.

She is hopeful that her business will grow and will continue to bring her enough income to sustain their daily needs. She also dreams of having a more spacious and durable house.

loans.use: To pay for four sacks of rice, 10 sacks of charcoal, groceries, soft drinks and other basic commodities

loans.name: Marinel

texts.en:
Marinel D. is a 30-year-old and mother to four; two girls and two boys. The eldest daughter is eight years old while the youngest is two years old.  She is happily married to Eddie who is 31 years old and a hired welder. She lives in the beautiful town of Tanay, Rizal province in the Philippines.
As a mother she dreams nothing but to bring good future for children, to bring her family out from poverty. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Her previous loan was used as rolling capital on her rice-resale business. The business is performing well since rice is the staple food for Filipinos.
Now on her 2nd loan, she is proposing a loan of 10,000 pesos as additional capital for her rice-resale business. This will be used to pay for 13 sacks of rice and its transportation expenses. She believes that she will gain more from this business. She dreams of expanding her business. She also aspires of sending her children to school until they all finish college and find jobs.

loans.use: To pay for 13 sacks of rice  for resale and its transportation expenses.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is a woman who believes that there is always a way to overcome poverty. She is 54 years old and a resident of the town of Tanay in the Rizal Province of the Philippines.  She is happily married to Francisco who is 46 years old and a construction worker. She is the mother of four sons.

She has been reselling vegetables and fruits for 27 years. She has been a busy woman since before her membership in ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, which she joined in 2008 to access rolling capital. Her previous loan was invested in the business. The business runs smoothly and it is the means by which she can pay the school fees for her children. She would like to invest more in this business.

Erlinda is proposing an amount of 10,000 pesos for her 2nd loan to use as additional capital for her business.  It will be used to pay for assorted stocks of vegetables and fruits and also for transportation expenses.  She hopes that as her business grows, she can earn more and save for the future of her children. Also, she dreams of having a service truck someday for the easy transportation of her goods.

loans.use: To purchase assorted stocks of vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica D. T. hails from the town of Jala-jala, Province of Rizal in the Philippines. She is 59-year-old wife to Carlito. They were blessed with four children; all boys and all of legal ages already. She believes that fighting against poverty is not a one-day journey.
With her aspiration to bring her family out from poverty, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVa partner in the Philippines, in 2005, with bagful of hope to have access to capital for her business. Prior to her membership in ASHI, she is already engaged in the transportation business with her husband as the driver of their jeep. Until, they were able additional unit of jeep and her eldest son is the one manages it. The business runs good and brings enough income in the family since it is considered to be their primary business. Being industrious in nature, Monica is also a manager of her general store as her another source of income.
Now on her 6th loan, she proposes a loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for the both of her businesses. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for the overhauling expenses for the engine of the jeep and portion of the amount will be used as additional capital for the general store business.
She dreams of having additional units of jeep for much bigger income. She also dreams of renovating her house into much spacious and durable one.

loans.use: To pay for the overhauling expenses for the engine of the jeep and portion of the amount will be used as additional capital for the general store business.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites M. is a woman who hails from the town of Pililia, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is 36-year-old wife to Jose, who is 36 years old and a farmer. They were blessed with five children; three males and two females. All her children are all studying.
In 2004, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with an aspiration to have access to capital for her business. For more than three years already, she is engaged with farming business and she is partnered by her husband. Farming of rice is a common source of livelihood in the upland and lowland villages in the country. Since rice is the staple food  for Filipinos, the demand for its grains is high.
She noticed that farming as a business brings bigger income and it gives her the chance to save and to sustain the needs of her children to school. Farming needs capital especially during cultivation until it grows and bear grains. She wanted to invest more on it.
Now on her 7th loan, she proposes a loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her farming business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for the metal cover of a handtractor and a motor engine to make it run. She is looking forward to send her children to school until they finish college and find jobs. She also aspires of purchasing farm lands in the future to expand her farming business.

loans.use: To pay for the metal cover of a handtractor and a motor engine.

loans.name: Sheren Gul Group

texts.en: Sheren Gul is a group composed of three members. Each member wants a loan to expand her family’s business, so they are requesting 30,000 AFN as a group. Sheren Gul wants a loan to support her husband’s general store. Bibi Sheren wants a loan for her husband’s small restaurant, while Anas Gul wants a loan for her carpet weaving business. They are very happy with this Afghani loan process.

loans.use: To expand 3 businesses: a general store, a restaurant & a carpet weaving enterprise

loans.name: Del Jan Group

texts.en: Del Jan is the group leader of Del Jan group. There are three members in this group. They are wants to take a loan for progress their business and make it larger. Del Jan wants to take a loan for her husband who his taxi . Zaba wants to take a loan for the business of embroidery. Sosan wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. And they are requested a group of loan 30000 Afghani. They are very happy from this process of loan in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For progress business

loans.name: Abdull Qasem Group

texts.en:
Abdull Qasem is the group leader of Abdull Qasem Group. There are three members in this group and each of them would like to receive a loan for their business. They have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani.

Adull Qasem wants to take a loan for his business as a mechanic.

Asmatallah wants to take a loan for his business of carpet weaving.

Khadeja wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store.

They are all very happy with this small loan process in this poor city in Afghanistan. They thank AFSG and all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand her husband's taxi business

loans.name: Fareui Group

texts.en: Fareui is the group leader of Fareui group. There are three members in this group. Each of them wants to takes a loan for expanding business and makes it larger. So the requested a group of loan 42000 Afghani. Fareui wants to take a loan for the business of bakery. Karema wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Nafes Gul wants to take a loan for her husband who his taxi. They are very thankful from AFS and Kiva lenders that can support all worlds.

loans.use: For progress business

loans.name: Bibi Saheb Group

texts.en:
Bibi Saheb is the group leader of Bibi Saheb Group. There are four members in this group and they would each like to expand their business. They want to take a loan of 30,000 Afghani.

Sabry Gull wants to take a loan for her business of quilt-making.

Bibi Saheb wants to take a loan for her family’s general store.

Gull Chahra wants to take a loan for her embroidery business.

Abdull M. wants to take a loan for his business as a butcher.

So they are all very thankful to AFS and to Kiva lenders who are able to support entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: For expanding a bakery

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita A. is a 47-year-old woman married to Ricardo, who is a 47-year-old farmer. She lives in the peaceful town of Jala-jala, in the province of Rizal, Philippines. She has no children, but she really longs for them.

Even though she has no children, she is still determined to have a source of income, aside from her husband's farming income. In 2001, she happily joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. When she received her first loan, she invested it in the resale of charcoal as her primary business. She is also involved in fishing and farming, both as secondary businesses.

As the years pass, she has noticed that her investment in the resale of charcoal is getting better, and it is providing her with good income. She buys the charcoal from the charcoal maker and resells it in their village. Now on her tenth loan, she proposes a loan of 20,000 Philippine Pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for two hundred sacks of charcoal for resale, and also its transportation expenses.

She dreams of expanding her business so that she can save for their future, and be able to build a more spacious and durable house.

loans.use: Purchase and transportation of bulk charcoal

loans.name: Qamar

texts.en:
Qamar wants to take out a loan for her husband, who is a tailor and works hard to earn money to meet the family’s needs. He needs to buy a new sewing machine for his shop because he has lots of problems with the old one. In addition, he wants to hire a student to support him in his business and to enlarge his business.

Qamar is the daughter of A. A.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with two children. Qamar is requesting an individual loan of 14,700 afghani. Qamar's husband is very glad that he has a chance to progress.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his farm stock

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a member of the Mgodi borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 26 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 5,2 years.

Gloria started her own clothing business selling clothes 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 95,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Gloria`s first loan from BRAC-Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Gloria hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy L. hails from the town of Jala-jala, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is the 30-year-old mother to two: a boy and a girl. She is happily married to Rally, 33 years old who is a jeepney (jeep used as public utility vehicle) driver. Daisy dreams of nothing but to give her children a decent life.

In the midst of crises in the world nowadays, poor countries like the Philippines are badly affected and for Daisy to depend on the meager income of her husband is not enough to sustain the needs of her family. In 2003, she decided to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. When she received her previous loans, she invested them in the maintenance of their jeepney as her primary business and part of the loans went to sewing as her secondary business. Both of her businesses ran smoothly and she is happy receiving a good income that she knows can sustain the needs of her family.

Now on her 6th loan, Daisy proposes a loan of PHP 20,000 to pay for four tires and overhauling of the engine, including labor expenses. Some of the amount will serve as rolling capital for her sewing business. She believes that, since the use of jeepneys as a means of transportation in the town and in the province is a must, her transportation business will grow. She dreams of sending her children to school, of buying a house and lot and of entering into a tire business.

loans.use: To pay for four tires, overhauling of the engine and labor expenses for her husband's jeepney

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying more seeds for his land

loans.name: Zainab Group

texts.en:
Zainab is the group leader of the Zainab Group. There are four members in this group. Each of them wants a loan to improve and enlarge their businesses, so they are requested a group loan of 20000 Afghani. 

Zainab wants a loan for her husband who has a watch shop. Farshta wants a loan for her tailoring business. Karema wants a loan for her embroidery business of embroidery. Habeba wants a loan for her carpet weaving business. 

They are very thankful that Kiva lenders can support all poor people.

loans.use: To improve their businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy some things necessary for farming

loans.name: Alba

texts.en:
Alba is a member of the Mgodi borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 26 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 2 years.

Alba started her own Tailoring business 4 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzania shillings.


This is Alba first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Alba hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda U., a native of the peaceful town of Morong, Rizal Province in the Philippines, is a 29-year-old mother of a boy and a girl and happily living with her husband Rodolfo, a 28-year-old farmer.

While her children are still small, Erlinda wants to invest and to look for additional sources of income in preparation for the future needs of her children, especially their school fees. In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines to have access to capital for her business. For almost ten years already, with her husband as her partner, she has been engaged in fishing as her primary and farming as her secondary business. Her businesses earn sufficient income to sustain the needs of her family.

Now on her ninth loan, she is seeking to borrow 20,000 pesos to pay for the repair of their fishing boat, purchase 30 kilos of fish nets and a 24 volt battery and to pay labor expenses. She believes that her fishing business will grow since fish are in demand in the market. She dreams of sending her children to school, having savings for the future, repairing her house and constructing a fish cage for her fishing business

loans.use: To pay for the repair of fishing boat, assorted 30 kilos of fish nets, 24 volt battery and labor expenses.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is a member of the Mgodi North borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 42 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 18,9 years .

Christina started her own food business selling chips 2 years ago,she works 13 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 120,000 Tanzania shillings.


This is Christina`s First loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more potatoes and cooking oil for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Christina hopes to save money and pay school fees.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes and cooking ol for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Ghulam Asan

texts.en: G. Asan is the son of G. A.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He has eight children and lives in a big family. He has a shop where he sells shoes. He started this business two years ago. He wants to expand his business and buy new designer shoes for his shop to have more clients and a high income. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani. He is happy that there is such a nice process that can support all the entrepreneurs and help them to improve their businesses.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Imakulata

texts.en:
Imakulata is a member oft he Mgodi borrower group in kinayanambo,,Iringa,she is 37 years old woman,she is separated from her husband and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 6 years.

Imakulata started  her own food business selling chips 6 years ago,she works 14 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Imakulata`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tanzania shillings in order to buy more potatoes and cooking oil for her business.


With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Imakulata hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes,cooking oil

loans.name: Aorng

texts.en: Mrs. Aorng S. lives in Roeu Sei Srouk village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Uk Bouy, is a car repairer. Since his business is doing well, he needs many car's accessories to fix the car for his customers. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Aorng S. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She is 53 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are electricians while another is attending the local school and the others stay at home to do housework. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loa to buy car's accessories to fix the car for his customers.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is a member of the Upendo East borrower group n Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 39 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 13,7,3 years.

Farida started her own clothing business selling clothes 10 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Farida`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,farida hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Phoeurk

texts.en: Mrs. Phoeurk K., born in 1989 and now living in Slaeng Village in Takeo Province, is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she needs a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice field to make the crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Keo Mean, owns a small ship that transports goods and passengers. This couple has a child who is yet too young to study. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the rice field to make it more productive.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a member of the Kinanambo borrower group in Kinyanambo,Iringa,she is 29 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 17,12,9 years.

Amina started her own business selling chicken 12 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Amina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more chicken.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan,Amina hopes to save money,pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buymore chicken

loans.name: Luon

texts.en: Mrs. Luon R. is a villager in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo province. She is a duck breeder to make duck eggs to sell in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Chea Mao, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. In his plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field is far from irrigation system. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Luon R. decided to ask for a loan to buy pump machine and she would use the rest of money to a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase income and improve her family living conditions with this loan. She is a 42-year-old mother of two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy pump machine and she would use the rest of money to a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Anastancia Lima

texts.pt:
Anastância Lina M. nasceu em Sofala, tem 36 anos de idade, vive maritalmente é mãe de três filhos com idades compreendidas entre os12 aos 22 anos. Os dois mais velhos abandonaram os estudos a mais nova é que esta a frequentar a 9ª classe. Para alem dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pela sua mãe, enviando lhe uma sexta básica no valor de 1.000.00MT mensalmente e consegue poupar 500.00MT por mês.

Anastância sai de Sofala com sua mãe ainda criança e passam a viver em casa do seu avo paterno. Inicia os estudos e quando freqüentava a 7 classe fica grávida do seu primeiro filho e teve que interromper os estudos e passa a viver em casa do seu marido, este que a maltratava dando batendo (violação domestica) e separa se dele.

Regressa para casa do seu avo e consegue arranjar um emprego na Escola Militar de Musica como praça e consegue se enquadrar no Ministério da Defesa apos a Desmobilização (Acordo Geral da Paz em 1994). Hoje e funcionaria permanente a mais de 6 anos como guarda fronteira trabalhando 24h( sendo um dia de trabalho e dois de folga)consecutivamente, auferindo um valor mensal de 5.200.00MT.

Aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00MT para dar continuidade da sua obra (compra de material de construção). Este é o  terceiro empréstimo de Anastancia na Hluvuu e primeiro com Kiva.
 O primeiro de 6.000.00MT foi usado para legalização do seu terreno, o segundo de 10.000.00MT para dar inicio da sua obra. E estes 15.000.00MT serão usados para dar continuidade do murro da sua residência.

Está confiante que vai pagar sem problemas, pois conta com ajuda do seu marido e irá pedir um outro credito para construir a casa do seu filho e um estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Anastancia Lina M. was born in Sofala, she is 36 years old and lives with his husband and her 3 children, who are between 12 and 22 years old. The two oldest stopped studying, is the youngest who is still studying on the 9th grade. Besides her children she is responsible for her mother, and send her a monthly allowance of 1,000MT and is able to save 500MT a month. Anastancia left Sofala with her mother when she was still a child and went to live at her grandfather’s house. She started studying but left school when she gets pregnant of her first child on the 7th grade and moved to her husband’s house, he hit her constantly and because of domestic violence she separates from him. She returned to her grandfather’s house and was able to obtain a job at the Military School of Music as a soldier and was able to work at the Defense Ministry after the General Peace Agreement in 1994. Now she is a permanent frontier guard with more than 6 years working 24 hours (1 days of work and 2 days of rest) consecutively, earning 5,200MT monthly. She approached Hluvuku and Kiva to request a loan for 15,000MT to keep on building (to buy construction material). This is her third loan with Hluvuku and first with Kiva. The first 6,000MT was used for legal paperwork of her land, and the second for 10,000MT was used to start the construction. And this one for 15,000MT will be used to continue with the wall of her house. She is confident she will pay without any trouble, because she has her husband’s help and she will return to request another loan to build a house for her son and a commercial store.

Translated from Portuguese by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Joana ( Namaacha)

texts.pt:
Joana T. nasceu em Matutuine (distrito a sul da província de Maputo), tem 36 anos de idade e solteira, não tem filhos e vive numa casa alugada pagando mensalmente um valor de 500.00MT. Não responsabiliza se por ninguém e consegue poupar por mês 1.000.00MT

Sai de matutuine devido à guerra, ainda criança, para cidade de Maputo com sua mãe esta que a abandonou e nunca mais se avistaram ate então. Após concluir a 10ª classe entra num curso de professorado que durou 2 anos. Depois é afecta para trabalhar no Município da Vila de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia como professora, primeiramente, numa Escola que dista 15 km da vila e seguidamente transferida para trabalhar noutra perto da Vila já a mais de 11 anos. É funcionaria permanente e aufere mensalmente um valor de 6.234.00MT.

Com o empréstimo que contraiu no (BIM) Banco Internacional de Moçambique, no valor de 50.000.00MT, para iniciar da sua obra que não terminou devido ao elevado custo do material. Aproxima se a Hluvuku e Kiva solicitando um empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00MT para compra de material de construção com objectivo de concluir a sua casa de alvenaria.  

Este e o primeiro empréstimo de 	Joana. Está confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir um novo para fazer mais uma obra na cidade capital para garantir a sua reforma.
texts.en:
Joana T. was born in Matutuine (a district south of the province of Maputo), she is 36 years old and is single, she doesn’t have children and lives at the rented house where she pays 500MT. She doesn’t have any other responsibilities and is able to save 1,000MT. She left Matutuine because of the war, when she was still a child, and went to live in Maputo with her mother who left her years before and never saw her until then. After finishing the 10th grade she started studying to be a teacher for 2 years. Then she obtained a job at the Municipality of Villa de Namaacha at the frontier with Suazilandia as a teacher, first at a school that was 15km away from the village and later on at another closer to the village, 11 years ago. She is now a permanent teacher and earns 6,234MT monthly. She got a loan from the (BIM) International Bank of Mozambique for 50,000MT to start the construction but she couldn’t finished due to the increased costs of materials. So she approached Hulvuku and Kiva to request a loan for 10,000MT to buy construction material in order to finish her house. This is Joana’s first loan, and she is confident she will be able to pay before the due date and will request another loan to build in the capital city to guarantee the reform.

Translated from Portuguese by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: Mrs. Nan V., a resident of An Doung Samreth Village in Takeo Province, is a Khmer noodle seller while her husband, Mr. Ouch Thorn, owns a piece of land upon which he cultivates rice. He currently needs some money to buy fertilizer and a pump machine to support his cultivation of the field, so Mrs. Nan V. is requesting a loan for this purpose. She is 44 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is enrolled in the local school and the youngest is yet too young to study. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a pump machine to support the cultivation of her husband's field.

loans.name: Bendila

texts.en:
Bendila B., a 30-year-old mother of six children and married to a clerk in the United Nations Mission in Sudan (UNMIS), has a business selling foodstuffs at a restaurant.  She is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to be cooked for sale in the restaurant.  In the future, Bendila intends to build a wholesale shop at Jebel Kujur market. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more food materials in the restaurant

loans.name: Rein

texts.en: Mrs. Rein K., who lives in Thnous Village in Takeo Province, is a farmer who owns a piece of land upon which she cultivates rice. She is also a pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding  business is doing well, she wants to expand by purchasing ten more piglets and pig food. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Keo Korn, a blacksmith, is shown on the right in the photo. This couple has four children, two employed in a garment factory while the others do housework at home and help with their parents' work.

loans.use: To buy ten more piglets and pig food for breeding.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Devotha

texts.en:
Devotha is a member of the Pangani borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 22 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.her child is aged 2 years.

Devotha started her own shop business selling clothes 5 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 210,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Devotha`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 210,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Devotha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more  clothes

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena B. is a woman of faith with the courage to bring her family out of poverty. She is 40 years old and a mother to six: four sons and two daughters. All of her children are still living with her. Her husband, Wilson, is a fisherman and is 38 years old. They live is the peaceful town of Jala-jala, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

Before, Rowena wanted to start a business with her husband, but they couldn’t because of lack of capital. With her desire to have access to capital, she joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. Her previous loans were carefully invested in the fishing business. Her husband goes to sea on the boat during the evening to catch fish and when he comes back in the morning, Rowena sells the catch in the village and in the market. The business runs smoothly and it brings her enough proceeds for her family.

Now on her 6th loan, Rowena requests 35,000 pesos as additional capital for her fishing business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for assorted fish nets, bamboo, gasoline for the engine and payment for labor to repair the boat.

Rowena dreams of sending her children to school until they finish college and find jobs so that they will not experience the kind of life she and her husband had. She also aspires to having a fish-cage someday.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment and to pay for boat repair

loans.name: Kuruthum

texts.en:
Kuruthum is a member of the Pangani borrower group in ilala,Iringa,she is 34 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children,her children are aged 15,07,04 years.

Kuruthum started her own shop business selling commodities like soap,cooking oil,sugar 16 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Kuruthum first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Kuruthum hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shop commodities

loans.name: Restetita

texts.en:
Restetita P. hails from the beautiful town of Jala-jala, Rizal province in the Philippines. she is 32 years old and married to Luiso, who is a fisherman and 39 years old. She is a mother to three; all females. The eldest daughter is 16 years old, while the youngest is 10 years old.
While her children are still small, she wants to strive hard and start a business that could sustain the needs of the family. In 2005, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines with hopes of having acces to capital to start a business. When she recieved her previous loans, she invested those in Hog Raising. She cultured pigs for four months and sell it to the market. The price of pigs in the country is high because of the demand of the pork.
She is so happy when her investments returns in double. She just need rolling capital to sustain the needs of the pigs especially its foods.
Now on her 6th loan, she proposes a loan of 35,000 pesos as additional capital for her hog raising business. Specifically, the loan will be used to pay for five piglets, sacks of assorted feeds (food), vitamins and for transportation expenses.
She is hopeful that her business will grow and she dreams of having a pig farm somdeday. She really aspires of sending her children to school until they finih college and find jobs.

loans.use: To pay for five piglets, sacks of assorted feeds (food), vitamins and for transportation expenses.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Idund D borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 31 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 20,15 years.

Joyce started her own shop business selling rice,cooking oil,salts 8 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn motherly profit approximately 195,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Joyce first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 250,000  Tsh in order to buy more shop commodities.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Joyce hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice,cooking oil,milk,salts

loans.name: Dédé

texts.fr: Madame Dédé est une femme qui habite le quartier Dèmakpoe à Lomé. Elle s’est spécialisée depuis 2005 dans le commerce d’alimentation générale. Cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge ; elle n’est pas mariée et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Elle a ouvert sa boutique dans sa maison, ce qui évite les frais de location. Elle est très connue par les gens de son  quartier, ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bonnes affaires. Pour renouveler son stock presque fini, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 bidons d’huile, 05 sacs de riz, 05 sacs de sucre, 03 boîtes de tomates, 01 boîte de lait et bien d’autres produits.
texts.en:
Ms. Dédé is a woman who lives in the Dèmakpoe district in Lomé. In 2005, she became specialized in the commerce of grocery items. This business enables her to support herself. She is not married and has no children to support. She has opened a store in her house, and this avoids the cost of leasing. She is well-known by people in her area, and business has been good as a result. To renew her almost-depleted inventory, she’s requesting a WAGES loan to buy 10 containers of oil, 5 sacks of rice, 5 sacks of sugar, 3 boxes of tomatoes, a box of milk, and many other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items

loans.name: Dicko

texts.en: Dicko J. lives in Gudele near the army baracks. She is 22 years old, married to a cashier in the Bank of Southern Sudan, and has five children. She retails in the bar selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan from Kiva in order to build a shop at the market. With the extra profits from her loan, Dicko is considering sending her children to school, paying their fees, and supporting them by providing scholastic materials like bags, uniforms and the many other requirements needed in school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a shop for her alcohol sales

loans.name: Maria

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de Baguida à Lomé et exerce comme activité la vente de charbon de bois. Elle a débuté cette activité depuis 1989 et ce commerce lui permet aussi d’aider financièrement son mari à subvenir à l’éducation scolaire de leurs 02 enfants. Elle vend du charbon lourd et léger, ce qui fait qu’elle a beaucoup de clients en tout temps. Actuellement elle a besoin d’argent pour couvrir ses frais de transport vers Atakpamé pour renouveler son stock qui finit. C’est pourquoi elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 50 sacs de charbon. Elle est très connue de beaucoup d’hôtels et de restaurants.
texts.en:
This is a lady who lives in the Baguida district of Lomé. She has a business selling charcoal. She started it in 1989, and it also enables her to help her husband financially to provide an education for their two children. She sells both hard and soft charcoal, and so she has many customers at any given time.
